results.justification: The paper states the goal is to create a higher-resolution "map" for physics learning and uses LLMs for automated labeling. The approach is clearly outlined.
The paper details the steps: 1) creating an atomic LO system, 2) using LLMs for labeling, and 3) proposing evaluation metrics. The experimental setup (Section 5.1) provides further detail.
The paper mentions datasets (OpenStax University Physics textbook, expert-created problem banks) but does not provide direct access to the raw or processed datasets.
While the OpenStax textbook is publicly available, the expert-created problem banks are not. There is no justification provided for why these are not shared.
Section 4 provides details on the structure of the learning objectives (LOs) and the questions, including the components of each LO and the source of the questions.
The paper describes how questions were selected from the course and OpenStax textbook (Section 4.2) and how experts labeled the LOs (Section 4.3).
The paper does not mention sharing the analysis code used for LLM experiments or evaluation.
Since the code is not shared, this criterion is not applicable.
The paper does not mention sharing code used for data preparation or preprocessing.
The paper clearly describes the evaluation metrics used (Exact Match, Jaccard Index, F1 Score, Distance-based Metric) in Section 3.1.
The results are presented with values for the evaluation metrics (e.g., Exact Match, Jaccard Index, F1 score, Distance) in Tables 5, 6, and 7.
Section 6.3 provides a qualitative error analysis with examples of LLM labeling, including expert commentary.
While the error analysis provides examples, the data coding and analysis process is not explicitly described or shared.
The results are presented in tables (5, 6, 7) and figures (2, 3, 4) with clear labels and descriptions.
Section 6.3 discusses potential reasons for LLM mislabeling and limitations of the LO system.
The paper does not mention or link to any preregistration.
